PIMS:4290 CC FSP "Belarus: LGGE Improving Energy Efficiency in Residential Buildings"

title.narrative: UNDP/GEF project: "Improving Energy Efficiency in Residential Buildings in the Republic of Belarus"
Improving Energy Efficiency in Residential Buildings in the Republic of Belarus
Improving Energy Efficiency in Residential Buildings in the Republic of Belarus

description.narrative: The objective of the project is to reduce the energy consumption and related GHG emissions with the focus on new residential buildings.
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Construction of the pilot energy efficient residential building in Minsk

description.narrative: seat of a first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Construction of the pilot energy efficient building in Mahilyow

description.narrative: seat of a first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Construction of the pilot energy efficient residential building in Hrodna

description.narrative: Energy - power generation
To reduce the energy consumption and related GHG emissions with the focus on new residential buildings.
Number of buildings designed and constructed in accordance with the new energy efficiency standards.

comment.narrative: At least 10% (around 80 buildings) of all new residential multi-storey buildings, for which the design is started during the last year of the project are integrating new EE measures into their design with the target of reducing their combined, annual energy demand for space heating and hot water below 60 kWh/m2.

There are no buildings constructed under the auspices of the project yet.
- The entire design and construction documentations have been completed by the project for three pilot buildings. The documentations have been submitted to the State Construction Expertise for approval. In these buildings, according to their design, the specific annual energy consumption for space heating and hot water supply will be less than 55 kWh/m2.
- Since 2013, 12 buildings, apart from 3 project pilot buildings above, are being designed using principles grounded and promoted by the project. In these buildings, the energy consumption for space heating already reduced to ca. 30 kWh/m2.

description.narrative: Amount of reduced CO2 emissions compared to the projected baseline

comment.narrative: Lifetime? reduction of 220,000 tons of CO2eq resulting from the energy saving in buildings, for which the construction has started or which have adopted into their design new energy efficiency elements that reduce the energy consumption for heating and hot water in the residential buildings below the current thermal standards in force.

17.9 thousand tons of CO2eq.
- The design and construction documentations for three pilot buildings (in Hrodna, Mahiliou and Minsk) developed by the project have been submitted for the required state expertise. New energy efficiency measures have been adopted into the design of these buildings (ventilation heat recuperation, heat pumps on sewage and geothermal sources, solar heaters and solar PV-panels). The project has been already proceeded to procurement of related equipment, accessories and tools. These provisions allow the projected annual specific energy consumption for space heating and hot water supply to be in the range of 50-60 kWh/m2 that is by ca. 60-70 kWh/m2 per year lower than in the baseline case.
- If this design value is proven by actual construction, the lifetime (30 years) GHG emission reduction will be at least 17.9 thousand tons of CO2eq for the three buildings in total.

description.narrative: Strengthened legal and regulatory framework and mechanisms to enforce the legislation for improving the energy efficiency of the building sector with the focus on new residential buildings
Status of the national laws and other regulatory documents controlling the energy consumption of the newly constructed buildings.

comment.narrative: Prescriptive thermal standards adopted in 2010 defining minimum mandatory U-values for the building envelope, corresponding to the average annual heat demand of 60 kWh/m2 for space heating of typical multi-apartment buildings and 120-130 kWh /m2 together with sanitary hot water preparation.

Revised minimum energy performance standards adopted for new construction and reaching a status of a law by the end of the project with a target of reducing the energy consumption of new residential buildings for space heating and hot water together below 60 kWh/m2.
An energy performance certification and labelling scheme for both new and existing buildings adopted and under implementation by the end of the project

No minimum energy performance standards reaching a status of a law have been adopted yet.
- The project elaborated a draft of the Technical Code “On Energy Efficiency of Buildings”, which is based on EU Directive 2010/31/EU concerning integral energy performance of residential buildings, along with the list of related national technical regulatory acts. These documents were incorporated into the Plan of State Standardization for 2015 and into the State Development Program of Technical Regulation, Standardization and Conformity Assessment in the Field of Energy Saving for 2011-2015. Both programmes were duly adopted, and the project submitted the drafts of elaborated documents to the Technical Committee for Standardization in the Field of Energy Efficiency (TCS-14) for consideration and approval. The said TCS-14 was created by the Ministry of Architecture and Construction due to initiatives and support provided by the project. Three project consultants were co-opted to be members of TCS-14, and one of them has become a chair of TCS-14.
- As an integral part of national applications to the said Technical Code, the project drafted some new standards. Some of these standards have been already submitted and adopted (in particular “Method of calculation of specific heat consumption for heating and ventilation in residential buildings”; "Energy performance of buildings. Assessment of overall energy consumption and energy performance of buildings"; "Energy efficiency of buildings. Methods for determination of energy efficiency and energy certification buildings "; amendments to “Thermal protection of buildings. Energy performance characteristics. Rules of definition”).
- The project has prepared a draft of the methodological guidelines, based on the IPMV-protocol and in line with the best international practice and with due account of national provisions, for energy audit and energy performance monitoring and calculation applicable to residential buildings. The draft has been verified during energy auditing of 30 multi-storey residential buildings in 2013-2015 and adjusted accordingly. It will be used for carrying out of energy audits of 25 other multi-storey residential buildings in 2015-2016 and further enter a corresponding adoption procedure. Four two-day training workshops were organized and held in 2013-2014 for more than 70 professional energy auditors. No energy performance certification and labeling scheme for residential buildings have been adopted yet.
- In technical standard "Energy efficiency of buildings. Methods for determination of energy efficiency and energy certification of buildings" the project and its partners first introduced a scheme similar to the energy performance certification system. This scheme is suggested in a building energy efficiency passport format, which is to be issued as an integral part of design and construction documentations, and contains all major requisites for energy performance certification. Next, in the second part of 2015, the project should elaborate practical procedures for the energy certification system and a system of monitoring and compliance checking applicable to residential buildings.
- To do this, the project organized and held two round-tables for relevant stakeholders, where main principles and framework of the certification system were discussed, and provided further necessary consulting services to the "StroyTechNorm" RUE and to members of the TCS-14. As of Nov 26, 2014, the suggestions mentioned above were considered and approved by the said Technical Committee for further adoption procedure. The project will continue its efforts in consulting the authorities, using in particular such instrument as TCS-14, until the said documents are duly adopted.

description.narrative: Enhanced capacity of the Belarusian specialists to implement and effectively enforce new energy efficiency standards and construction norms with the initial focus on new residential buildings.
Demonstrated capacity of the Belarussian building sector specialist to integrate new EE approaches and measures into the design of the buildings and to implement them in practice.

comment.narrative:
Non-integrated design of the buildings just complying with the current prescriptive thermal standards in force.
Lack of capacity of the public authorities to effectively supervise and enforce the implementation of the planned new, overall energy performance based norms and standards.

Integrated, energy efficient building design approach together with buildingsâ€™ overall energy performance based design principles adopted into the work of at least 30% of all local design institutes as well as into the curricula of all educational institutes in Belarus educating new architects and building construction and HVAC engineers.
By the end of the project, at least 50 experts from each key professional group (see outputs 2,2-2.6) and 200 university students have taken and successfully passed courses on energy efficient building design and construction.Key public authorities responsible for supervision and enforcement of the planned new norms and regulations trained,

6%
- There are already 7 local design institutes (i.e., NIPTIS, MAPID, Hrodnagrazhdanproekt, Gomelgrazhdanproekt, Saint-Gobain Construction Product BelRus, Tenth UNR, Minskproekt), out of ca. 120 design institutes operating in the field of civil construction engineering, which are introducing in their practice design and construction of residential buildings with energy efficiency improvement components developed and advocated by the project.
- The project developed and disseminated about 40 special technical reports and guidelines on energy efficiency design principles. The recommendations with cost efficiency analysis of different technical options applicable to the development of energy efficient residential buildings were prepared and discussed with stakeholders. The recommendations are intended to be tested during the development of pilot buildings and will be included in national technical regulations and standards. More than 70 specialists.
- The analysis of target groups along with assessment of needs in their capacity building has been conducted and the capacity building action plan for 2014-2016 has been compiled, discussed with Energy Efficiency Department and other stakeholders and approved. Training textbooks have been drafted and disseminated.
- More than 70 specialists has developed their skills and increased knowledge for leading and managing effective energy audit in residential houses during three two-day training courses organized in Sep, Oct and December 2014. One training course was conducted during actual energy audit measurements on-site.
- More than 70 specialists has taken and passed six-day training courses held in Hrodna and Minsk on energy efficient building design and construction, new energy efficiency improvement policy, norms and standards. The trainings were attended by 29 companies (designers, engineers, builders, construction inspectors, utilities representatives, etc.).
- The project provided support and organized logistics for 9 study visits and 10 international events abroad where about 30 decision-makers, designers, builders and other relevant specialists have become acquainted with design, construction and operation practices as well as with legal framework, standards and policies exercised in four leading European countries (Germany, Austria, England and France) in the field of energy efficient residential buildings. No syllabus related to energy efficient building design principles has been adopted into the curricula of target educational institutes in Belarus yet. No student has passed the courses yet.
- The critical analysis of curricula of different relevant universities has been conducted and the proposals for its improvement and updating have been presented in a project report along with a list of suggested university courses. Based on the report, recommendations for relevant university curricular updates have been drafted, presented and approved at two round-tables (about 60 representatives of stakeholders have participated).
- Three new courses related to the best international and national practice in the field of design and construction of energy efficient residential buildings were suggested and presented by the project. During round-table discussions held in the Belarusian National Technical University conjointly with Scientific Council Meeting with presence of representatives from 14 faculties of 7 universities, three national universities agreed to include these new courses in their syllabi. The decision has been made to continue cooperation with the said faculties in order to further adjust the curricular materials prepared by the project to current syllabi.

description.narrative: Demonstrated energy and cost-saving potential of new energy efficiency measures in at least three new residential buildings in two Belarusian cities
Status of the demonstration projects.

comment.narrative: N/A

Each of the 3 demonstration buildings constructed and reaching the target for annual external energy demand for space heating and hot water equal or less than 60 kWh/m2, and their energy consumption and other performance (living comfort etc.) monitored for at least one full year. Full completion of this outcome without project extension is moderately unlikely because of one-year delay of the project start. If the documented, disseminated and institutionalized project results should be based on the results of the three buildings being built, then completion of this Outcome without project extension is unlikely.
The baseline costs of the 3 demo buildings is covered in full by the project's cofinancing resources and the GEF financing for incremental EE measures will not exceed 15% of the total construction costs of each demo building.

None of the three demonstration buildings has been constructed and monitored yet.
- Background studies, preconstruction simulations and exploratory designs of measures, technological methods, installations and equipment for energy efficiency improvement of three pilot buildings and design of all three selected pilot buildings have been completed along with application of integrated building design principles and taking into account new technologies and approaches suggested and formulated by the project.
- The design and construction documentations of all three pilot buildings (in Hrodna, Mahiliou and Minsk) have been developed and submitted to the state expertise for approval. The construction documentation of the pilot building in Hrodna has been approved. Such approval for construction documentations of other two buildings is expected in July 2015.
- The project has already procured of about 15% of all equipment, accessories and tools and started procurement procedures for the rest. In line with the commitments assumed in writing by the project partners, they have covered the baseline cost of design and construction documentations for all three pilot buildings. Recently, the GrodnoGrazhdanProject informed the PIU that they will not be able to provide further sustainable financing of the pilot house in Grodno. The PIU and UNDP CO have, in cooperation with the Head of EE Department, approached the Grodno authorities to settle this issue. As a result, another builder is ready to take over the initiative and commit itself to provide necessary financing of the construction in Grodno. The project is currently waiting for a formal letter. The two other partners re-confirmed in writing their financial commitments to support the baseline construction, proven by corresponding Oblast authorities, and submitted timeframes for design and construction of pilot buildings in Minsk and Mogilev. According to the design and construction documentations, the energy performance of these buildings will be in line with the outcome target, which stipulates for annual external energy demand for space heating and hot water supply to be equal or less than 60 kWh/m2, and the cost of incremental energy efficiency measures will not exceed 15% of the total construction costs.

description.narrative: Documented, disseminated and institutionalized project results providing a basis for further replication.

Status of the planned public outreach activities
Status of the entity to follow up and continue the activities initiated by the project
Number of visit and downloads from the project website

comment.narrative: N/A

Planned public outreach activities successfully completed
An entity to follow up and, as applicable, to continue the activities initiated by the project has been designated with adequate resources to perform its work.
At least 100 hits and 20 downloaded documents per month from the project website by outside visitors

Public outreach activities being successfully implemented:
- 14 communication campaigns (5 international conferences, 5 round tables, 2 international seminars abroad, one press-conference, 6 training workshops, one Earth Day Event, one 3D-Picture Event, two exhibitions).
- 39 press-releases and 67 articles published in web-based media.
- 148 technical reports and 16 brochures printed or published in web-based media.
- 40 news pieces broadcasted. The partnership network includes more than 25 media resources.
- Support has been provided for 2012-2013 and 2013-2014 Energy Marathon Republican Contest. The PMU was taking part in the Contest Committee. The Contest materials have been prepared, published and disseminated in 500 CDs among schools, relevant Universities and the Ministry of Education. No state agency with a responsibility to monitor the energy savings and CO2 emission reductions in residential buildings has been mandated and capacitated yet. This activity was initially planned for 2015-2016. In average per month, 190 hits and 1700 documents are being downloaded by outside visitors.
- The project website test version was created as of 01.12.2013. The fully operated version was launched on 19.12.2013. The website is being regularly updated (www.effbuild.by).

description.narrative: Landscape approach to management of peatlands aiming at multiple ecological benefits.
Landscape approach to management of peatlands aiming at multiple ecological benefits
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: To promote a landscape approach to management of peatlands so as to conserve biodiversity, enhance carbon stocks, and secure multiple ecosystem services with demonstration in the Poozerie landscape.

description.narrative: Environment - policy, planning and administration

To promote a landscape approach to management of peatlands that conserves biodiversity, enhances carbon stocks, ensures sustainable land management, and sustainable forest management, with demonstrations in a number of pilot sites (peatland PAs, agricultural peatlands, and forested peatlands)
Extent of peatland area that is brought under an effective, landscape-based, conservation and/or sustainable use regime under the framework of a National Strategy for Peatlands (NSP)

comment.narrative: Currently there is no NSP; there are a few, disparate efforts through past and ongoing donor-funded projects to restore, conserve and sustainably use peatlands

122,270 ha
(Of which, 30,301 ha are existing peatland national zakazniks where management effectiveness is improved; 25,036 ha are new local zakazniks; 45,000 ha is the network of environmental corridors; 15,000 ha of drainage networks on agricultural peatlands from which sedimentation is to be reduced; 4,311 ha are re-wetted agricultural lands; 495 ha are arable peatlands converted to meadows; 100 ha are arable peatlands subject to layered ploughing; and 2,027 ha are re-wetted forest peatlands)

59,337 ha +
13,927 ha reserved at the local level for establishing of 7 new reserves (25,000 ha of new reserves will be officially gazzeted by end of 2016); An a network of environmental corridors covering 45,000 ha established;
An engineering project to establish a drainage network covering 15,000 ha on agricultural peatlands developed to reduce adverse impact of anthropogenic run-offs from land-reclamation systems on ecosystems of the Zvanest reserve; works will be completed by mid 2016
An engineering project for re-wetting of 3,455 ha of agricultural lands developed; 400 ha of arable peatlands converted to meadows; 10 ha of arable peatlands subject to layered ploughing; and engineering projects for re-wetting of 3,384 ha forested peatlands developed.

description.narrative: Landscape approach to peatlands conservation and sustainable use enshrined in national policy and implemented through a network of PAs in the Poozerie landscape
Cross-sectoral WG for promoting a landscape approach to peatlands conservation and sustainable use

comment.narrative: None exists at present
Working Group formed by Year 1 and receives capacity building support from partner international peatland conservation organizations
Another two meetings of the Working Group took place in November 2014 and February 2015, where main provisions of the Strategy and Schemes were approved

description.narrative: Criteria and methodologies for assessment of peatlandsâ€™ state, function and services

comment.narrative: Criteria exist but they only take into account economic benefits
Criteria and methodology developed by Year 2 and includes ecological criteria (in the form of recommendations/ instructions)
A technical code on criteria, including ecological ones for peatlands use, developed and duly approved by Ministry of Environemnt on f June 26th 2015 (17.12-08-2015 (33140)

description.narrative: Inventory of all peatlands

comment.narrative: Outdated listing of peatlands exist and it is spotty (not comprehensive)
Current and comprehensive listing of peatlands status, functions, services (based on above criteria) by Year 3
Inventories of peatlands in three (MInsk, Brest and Vitebsk) out of six target regions completed. Inventory of remaining peatlands shall be completed by end of 2015.

description.narrative: National Strategy for Peatlands

comment.narrative: Old Scheme ended in 2010 and emphasis was on peat mining and agriculture
New 20-year strategy that takes economic and ecological benefits into account in determining use of peatlands by Year 4

Strategy for sustainable use of peatlands until 2030 and Schemes of peatland distribution with instructions on the use of peatlands are developed and being reviewed. Final documents are expected by December 2015.

description.narrative: Enhanced management effectiveness at existing PAs as measured by METT

comment.narrative:
Yelnya: 48%
Morochno: 20%

Yelnya: 60%
Morochno: 45%
METT assessment is planned for 2015-2016 after completion of works on restoration of hydrological regime in Yelnya and development of the management plan for Morochno.

description.narrative: Emission reductions through re-wetting of disturbed areas in Yelnya PA (see table on carbon benefits below for details)

comment.narrative: In the baseline scenario emissions reduction would be 0 tCO2equ
Target emission reduction over 20 years 545,624.20 tCO2equ

Contract is under implementation for assessment of emission in Yelnya before completion of works on restoration of hydrological regime. In 2016 similar studies will be conducted to assess changes in GHG fluxes after re-wetting

description.narrative: Enhanced management effectiveness at planned local reserves as measured by METT (local reserves have been clustered in to 3 groups based on geographical location)

comment.narrative:
Vitebsk Poozerie Cluster (Krasniy Moch, Uzgon, Bolshoy Moch, Potoki, Lebediny Moch, Zaborovski Moch, Rossonski Moch): 6%
Eastern Cluster (Esmonovski Moch, Ushlovskoe, Yasen, Velikiy Ostrov, Oster, Beloe): 6%
Central Cluster (Ushanskoe, Chertovo boloto, Surazhinskoe, Turshevka-Chertovo, Ositskoe): 6%
Each of the 3 clusters: 42%
Management effectiveness will be evaluated after protected areas establishment in November-December 2015.

description.narrative: A network of local caretakers is operational in the internationally important peatland PAs

comment.narrative: At present, system of local caretakers are in 8 important peatland PAs
Network exists for 18 internationally important peatland PAs by Year 3

Activities are planned for 2015-2016. In 2015 an agreement with a leading national NGO in this area (Akhova ptushak Batskaushchyny) was reached and preliminar financial and working plan was worked out. In September 2015 official agreement on implementation of this activity will be signed. It presumes using of NIM modality.

description.narrative: Plans for restoration of hydrological regime in the Yelnya peatland PA are elaborated and implemented

comment.narrative: Plan for Yelnya at the stage of elaboration, but not finished and not implemented.
Plans are elaborated and implemented by Year 4
The project is developed and passing through state ecological expertise. Hydroregime is expected to be restored by December 2015

description.narrative: Increase in local tourism organization income from wildlife viewing

comment.narrative: Approx. $1200
Increase in revenue from wildlife viewers estimated at $5,000 per year at all pilots
Assesment of financial incomes as result of undertaken activities wil be conducted in 2015-2017 for the pilot project's territories (reserves Nalibokski and Zvanets)

description.narrative: Increase in local hunter association income from sustainable hunting

comment.narrative: Increase in revenue from sustainable hunting estimated at $2,500 per year per site
Assesment of financial incomes by local hunter association as result of undertaken activities wil be conducted in 2015-2017 for the pilot project's territories (reserves Nalibokski and Zvanets)

description.narrative: A network of environmental corridors in the Vitebsk Oblast Poozerie landscape, ensuring the continuity of the natural landscapes and unrestricted wildlife migration

comment.narrative: Isolated elements of the network are in place, which are not considered in territorial planning
An environmental network is developed, comprised of the key territories and environmental corridors linking bogs and wet areas together by Year 3
Environmental Network for Vitebsk Oblast Poozerie was established and duly approved be the Ministry of Environment and Vitebsk Regional Executive Committee

description.narrative: Flow of polluted waters from drainage areas into nearby natural water bodies

comment.narrative: Baseline level of pollutant flow to be measured in first quarter of project
Decrease in pollutants from baseline levels by 50% by Year 4, which creates conditions for the restoration of biodiversity
The project is developed and passing through state ecological expertise. Project is expected to be implemented by December 2015

description.narrative: Restoration and management of degraded agricultural and forested peatlands for improved biodiversity conservation, sustainable land management and carbon sequestration within landscapes

comment.narrative: 60 cm and more below soil
10 to -30 cm (except for Mgle and Yurievo where target is 0 to -40 cm
Measurements will be conducted in 2015-2017 after completion of respective construction works at 3,455 ha

description.narrative: Water levels at re-wetted forest peatlands (F3 pilots)

comment.narrative: 40-80 cm below soil
0-30 cm below soil
Measurements will be conducted in 2015-2017 after completion of respective construction works at 3,384 ha.

description.narrative: Perennial grass cover at arable peatlands that are converted to improved grassland (F2 pilots)

comment.narrative: More than 70% of pilot sites are arable land
100 ha of F2 sites are improved grassland
400 ha of F2 sites have been converted to improved grassland

description.narrative: Content of organic matter in soil (F4 sites)

comment.narrative: Organic matter in soil 50-70% (F4 sites)
Content of organic matter in soil decreases by no more than 5%
Deep ploughing of 10 hectares completed. Organic matter monitoring is ongoing. Results of the organic content analysis will be available in 2016

description.narrative: Improvement in biodiversity indicator species at pilot sites

comment.narrative: See baseline values for pilot sites in table below
See target values for pilot sites in table below

Biodiversity inventory at pilot sites (8 territories of over 8,000 ha) was completed before re-wetting. Flora and fauna charactiristic were recorded, It was shown that for the pilot territories the most typical vegetation type is pine forests growing in an unstable hydrological regime with signs of digression. Populations of birds indictor species are characterized by significant lower levels in comparison with target numbers. Monitoring works will continue in 2015-2017 after re-wetting.

description.narrative: Reduction in GHG emissions and enhanced carbon sequestration at pilot sites

comment.narrative: See baseline values for pilot sites in table below
See target values for pilot sites in table below

Respective assessments for sites of agriculture lands completed before re-wetting (3,455 ha). Total GHG emissions before intervention: 33,030 ?(??2 eq.)/year.
Respective assessments for other sites (forested peatlands) completed in 2014-2015 before re-wetting for 3,384 ha. Total GHG emissions before intervention: 15,031 ?(??2 eq.)/year

description.narrative: Revised GESTs developed covering drained and rewetted bogs for recently rewetted agricultural fens, and for the transient stages

comment.narrative: Current GESTs apply only to extracted peatland areas
Gaps in GESTs are filled by Year 4 such that agricultural and forestry biotopes are covered

Continuation of two-year monitoring of greenhouse gases fluxes agricultural on and forestry biotopes.
As of of 30 June 2015 all investigated sites were recorded for GHG exchange fot 19 month.
Emission of CO2 for one-year period was 464,46±26,66 g(??2-C)m-2 for fen in transition stage (meadow grass (Phleum) on drained peat soils for agricultural purposes, with changed land use from cultivated crops to perennial grass meadow).
emission of CO2 was 511 ±27,8 g(??2-C)m-2 for biotope dominated by Polytrichum commune on raised bogs with disturbed hydrological regime.
Emission of CO2 was 391±37 g(??2-C)m-2 for biotope dominated by Calluna vulgaris on raised bogs with disturbed hydrological regime.
Emission of N2O was negligible only on drained bogs sites. On fens in transition stage site N2O emission was 644 mg(N2O-N) m-2 for one-year period.
The CH4 emission was negligible at all sites
